author: Special Correspondent
text:
Residents of Banayan’s home to be trained in hand spinning and hand weaving to make products and earn an income

As many as 12 looms of four types have been inaugurated at Banyan’s home in Mogappair —File Photo

Thirty-year-old Shireen* has never used a loom before. But just recently, she has taken to it and is enjoying weaving — “I can easily do it,” she said.

Shireen is one of the four women, residents of The Banayan’s home in Mogappair, who will soon be trained in hand spinning and hand weaving to make products ranging from table runners to shawls, which can potentially be sold for an income.

On Tuesday, the organisation that works in the field of mental health, inaugurated 12 looms of four types for 16 of their residents to use.

“These looms have been modified to allow people with a wide range of disabilities to use them,” explained Archana Padmakar, assistant director at The Banyan. After about three months, she said, a plan to market and sell the products would be devised. “The weaving will have a therapeutic effect too,” she said.

The four women are going to be trained at Shuttles and Needles, a centre that promotes hand spinning and weaving as a hobby and craft. “We already work with seven special schools in Chennai and also supply raw materials to them. The Banyan wants this to be a part of their vocational therapy,” said R. Naresh, managing director.

The looms were made in New Zealand, and the centre manufactured and supplied yarn that could be used with the looms, he said.

It is extremely challenging to find a skill to help get people living with mental illnesses get productive employment, said K.V. Kishore Kumar, director of The Banyan. “Many traditional occupations such as pottery, basket and candle making are not very economically viable. But weaving potentially high-end products, where there is scope for innovation and creativity, could be profitable,” he said.

(*Name changed)

Shuttles and Needles, which promotes hand spinning as a hobby, will train them
title: Helping them weave their way to wellness
